conclusion: Identify what the graph actually shows
Although the statement says 'x-t graph', the vertical label is 'x / t (m s⁻¹)'. The unit m s⁻¹ is the unit of velocity, so the ordinate must in fact be the instantaneous velocity v(t).

premise: The unit m s⁻¹ is the unit of velocity, so the ordinate must in fact be the instantaneous velocity v(t).
conclusion: Therefore we are dealing with a straight-line v–t graph.
At t = 0 s the graph gives v = 10 m s⁻¹.
The dashed extension passes through v = 0 m s⁻¹ at t = –2 s.

premise: At t = 0 s the graph gives v = 10 m s⁻¹. The dashed extension passes through v = 0 m s⁻¹ at t = –2 s.
conclusion: Determine the acceleration (slope of the v–t graph) Slope a = Δv / Δt = (10 m s⁻¹ – 0 m s⁻¹) / (0 s – (–2 s)) = 10 m s⁻¹ / 2 s = 5 m s⁻².
Use the acceleration to find the velocity at t = +2 s v(2 s) = v₀ + a t = 10 m s⁻¹ + (5 m s⁻²)(2 s) = 10 m s⁻¹ + 10 m s⁻¹ = 20 m s⁻¹.

premise: The car’s speed at the end of the 2nd second is 20 m s⁻¹.
conclusion: Final answer: The car’s speed at the end of the 2nd second is 20 m s⁻¹.
